content.title: Circadian Rhythm Disruption and Jet Lag Syndrome
content.summary: Neurophysiology of circadian rhythm regulation by the suprachiasmatic nucleus and mechanisms of disruption in transmeridian travel
key_points: Circadian rhythm is controlled by suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) - the master clock
Recovery rate: ~1 day per time zone crossed (faster westward, slower eastward)
Eastward travel is harder: advancing the clock is more difficult than delaying
Light exposure is the most powerful circadian entrainment tool (zeitgeber)
Strategic melatonin use (0.5-3mg) can accelerate adaptation
Jet lag impairs memory consolidation, attention, and decision-making
Pre-adaptation (shifting sleep schedule before travel) reduces symptoms

statement.text: Jet lag (circadian dysrhythmia) occurs when rapid transmeridian travel desynchronizes the internal circadian clock, controlled by the suprachiasmatic nucleus, from the external light-dark cycle. This misalignment impairs sleep quality, cognitive performance, and physiological function. Strategic light exposure and melatonin timing can accelerate re-entrainment.
statement.formal: Jet Lag Severity ∝ (Time Zones Crossed × Direction Factor); Recovery ≈ 1 day/zone; Eastward > Westward difficulty

explanation.intuition: Your body runs on a 24-hour internal clock synchronized to your home time zone by the master pacemaker in your hypothalamus (SCN). When you fly across time zones, your internal clock and the external world are out of sync. Your body needs time (roughly one day per hour of time difference) to reset through light exposure.
explanation.key_insight: The direction of travel matters: traveling west 'extends' your day (easier to stay up late), while traveling east 'shortens' it (harder to fall asleep earlier). This asymmetry reflects the natural tendency of the human circadian system to run slightly longer than 24 hours.

definitions_glossary.circadian_rhythm: ~24-hour internal biological clock regulating sleep-wake cycles, hormones, and metabolism
definitions_glossary.suprachiasmatic_nucleus: Master circadian pacemaker in hypothalamus; receives light input from retina via retinohypothalamic tract
definitions_glossary.jet_lag: Temporary circadian rhythm sleep disorder (G47.25) from rapid transmeridian travel causing circadian misalignment
definitions_glossary.melatonin: Hormone secreted by pineal gland in darkness; signals night to circadian system
definitions_glossary.zeitgeber: Environmental cue that entrains circadian rhythm (light is strongest)
definitions_glossary.phase_advance: Shifting circadian rhythm earlier (required for eastward adaptation)
definitions_glossary.phase_delay: Shifting circadian rhythm later (required for westward adaptation)
definitions_glossary.circadian_desynchrony: Internal clock misaligned with external light-dark cycle

pathophysiology.mechanism: Transmeridian travel → Light-dark cycle shift → SCN receives conflicting signals → Peripheral clocks (liver, gut, muscles) lag behind → Multi-system desynchrony → Sleep disruption + Cognitive impairment + GI symptoms + Mood changes

neuroanatomy.input_pathway: Retinohypothalamic tract from intrinsically photosensitive retinal ganglion cells (ipRGCs)
neuroanatomy.output_pathways: Pineal gland (melatonin), autonomic nervous system, endocrine axes

pre_travel.eastward: Shift sleep 30-60min earlier per day for 3 days before departure
pre_travel.westward: Shift sleep 30-60min later per day for 3 days before departure

light_exposure.eastward: Seek bright light in morning; avoid evening light
light_exposure.westward: Seek bright light in evening; avoid early morning light
light_exposure.timing_rule: Avoid light in the 4 hours before your home bedtime

melatonin.timing: Take at destination bedtime, especially for eastward travel

behavioral: Stay awake until local evening (brief naps ≤20min if needed)
Avoid alcohol and caffeine near bedtime
